derivation.yuyuan_name: late 16th cent. (in sense 2): probably of Scandinavian origin. The early sense 'stump sticking out from a tree trunk' gave rise to a US sense 'submerged piece of timber obstructing navigation', of which sense 1 is originally a figurative use. Current verb senses arose in the 19th cent

entry.tran: 小困难;小问题;不利条件
entry.def: A snag is a small problem or disadvantage.

example.ex: A police clampdown on car thieves hit a snag when villains stole one of their cars...
example.tran: 警方打击偷车贼的行动遭遇了一点小挫折：匪徒偷走了一辆警车。

example.ex: The school deals exclusively with children of high academic ability. There is a snag though, it costs £9,600 a year.
example.tran: 这所学校只招收学习能力强的孩子，不过还有个小问题——它每年的学费高达 9,600 英镑。

entry.def: If you snag part of your clothing on a sharp or rough object or if it snags, it gets caught on the object and tears.

example.ex: She snagged a heel on a root and tumbled to the ground...
example.tran: 她脚后跟被一个树根绊了一下，踉踉跄跄地摔倒在地上。
荆棘把他的西服钩住了。

means.word_mean: 2. a dead tree that is still standing, usually in an undisturbed forest;

sentences.sentence: "a snag can provide food and a habitat for insects and birds"

means.word_mean: 3. an opening made forcibly as by pulling apart;

sentences.sentence: "there was a rip in his pants"

means.word_mean: 2. get by acting quickly and smartly;

means.word_mean: (尤指潜伏的)困难， (未料到的)障碍，问题，麻烦

sentences.en: The only snag is, I can’t afford it!
sentences.cn: 惟一的困难是, 我付不起这钱！

means.word_mean: (被尖锐物)挂住, 钩住,挂破

sentences.en: She snagged her tights on the rough edge of the chair.
sentences.cn: 她的紧身衣裤被粗糙的椅子边缘勾住了。

sentences.en: She got snagged by the police while stealing the purse.
sentences.cn: 她在偷钱包时被警察一把抓住了。
